title: Best bike frame bags 2025: Spacious and aero bikepacking options

Best bike frame bags 2025: Spacious and aero bikepacking options

A bike frame bag makes good use of the space inside your bike’s front triangle, adding significant extra carrying capacity that’s low profile and easy to reach. It’s also fairly low down and central on your frame, so it’s less likely to affect the bike’s handling.

If you’ve already maxed out on a handlebar bag, a top tube bag and a saddle bag, it’s a great addition to your bikepacking bag ensemble. It may even make your bike more aero by providing a longer tail to smooth the airflow behind your head tube.

You can buy frame bags that fill the front of your triangle, run along the length of the top tube or sit at the top tube/seat tube junction. Some completely fill the front triangle, although then you’ll need somewhere else for your water bottles – it’s worth considering the interaction with your other equipment when choosing.

Frame bags can take a bit of getting used to, as they can potentially rub on your legs when you pedal. Most have a slimline shape and a rigid structure to avoid bulging though. They’re a good place to store the essentials you might need for repairs on the road and a phone, as well as being a handy place for energy gels or other food.

Read on for our pick of the best bicycle frame bags.

Why trust Cyclist‘s advice?

We’re all up for a bikepacking adventure here at Cyclist, riding self-supported to Tunisia and even braving bears in Alaska. Needless to say, both required a fair chunk of luggage, including a frame bag, so we know what to look for when choosing bike luggage and what to pack for a bikepacking trip.

We’re not paid for our recommendations or for product placement, so you can trust Cyclist to provide you with unbiased advice.

Best bike frame bags 2025

Alpkit Deluge Frame Pack

£49.99 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 2.5, 4, 6 litre

Alpkit’s Deluge frame bag is made from waterproof recycled fabric, with welded seams and a waterproof two-way zip on each side covered by a storm flap. The 55mm width should fit nicely under the top tube of most bikes.

The pack is secured by three rubber-backed Velcro straps, there’s a side pocket for a phone and a cable port for power-ups for cycling computers or other electronics. Alpkit also sells a wedge pack and frame pack with lower capacities up to 2.2 litres if you want to carry less.

  • Buy now from Alpkit (£49.99)

Apidura Expedition Frame Pack

From £93 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 3, 4.5, 5, 5.3, 6.5 litre

Apidura sells three frame bag ranges, with the Racing bags offering capacity of up to 4 litres, the Backcountry bags designed for MTB use and the Expedition bags aimed at road riding and touring use. The Expedition Frame Pack comes in three lengths to fit different size bike frames with up to 5.3 litre capacity, as well as two Tall options with up to 6.5 litres storage. The design allows room to fit water bottles, but additionally there’s a Full Frame Pack, allowing you to stow up to 14 litres.

All are held in place with three velcro straps on the top tube, a head tube strap, a down tube strap and a seat tube strap. They have welded seams, waterproof zips and a port for a battery lead or hydration tube.

  • Buy now from Condor Cycles (£93)

Evoc Frame Pack WP

From €80 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 1.5, 3.5 litres

Evoc’s frame bag is available in two sizes, with welded seams and waterproof zips ensuring water resistance. It attaches to the top tube with three velcro strips, as well as to the down tube and/or the seat tube, depending on where you choose to position it. Evoc supplies protective strips to help prevent scratching of your frame.

The bag is slender at 50mm width, so it’s less likely to interfere with your legs when pedalling and there’s a large reflective logo to increase your visibility.

  • Buy now from Tweeks Cycles (£38.99)

Ortlieb Frame-Pack RC

From £110 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 4, 6 litre

The Frame-Pack RC provides a little extra capacity over Ortlieb’s 3 or 4 litre Toptube bag, but still allows you to squeeze a down tube bottle below it. The RC signifies roll closure, so there’s a large opening. Without zips it should keep contents water-free, although at the expense of less usability when on the move.

Six hook and loop straps with adjustable mounting points help to keep the bag stable. There’s also a version with a waterproof zip in place of the roll top sold in the same sizes.

  • Buy now from Cyclestore (£85)

Oxford Aqua Evo Frame Pack

£39.99 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 4 litres

An inexpensive option, Oxford Products’ frame bag comes in one size with 4 litre capacity and is available in black as well as fluo orange. Oxford says it’s IPX6 rated and it includes two internal storage compartments.

There’s a total of six hook and loop straps, while the 70mm width and 110mm depth should avoid interference when riding.

  • Buy now from Decathlon (£39.99)

Rapha Explore Frame Pack

£90 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 2.5, 3, 4 litre

Rapha’s frame pack is available in three sizes, with contents accessible from both sides. At 55mm wide, it shouldn’t interfere with pedalling. It’s water resistant and held in place by three Velcro top tube straps, plus down tube and seat tube straps. It should allow space for you to fit water bottles in larger frame sizes.

  • Buy now from Rapha (£90)

Restrap Frame Bag

From £62.99 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 2.5 – 4.5 litres half frame; 6 – 9 litres full frame, plus custom

Restrap makes a range of frame bags from a 2.5 litre wedge bag up to full frame options, as well as lighter weight Race bags. You can even order a custom frame bag to fit the specific dimensions of your bike.

Restrap uses wide rubberised straps for a firm grip on the frame. There are reflective waterproof zips, inner mesh pockets and a cable slot. The 60mm width should fit nicely under your top tube.

  • Buy now from Ribble Cycles (£59.99)

Riverside ADVT 500 Bikepacking Half-Frame Bag

From £24.99 | View offer

Decathlon sells a range of well-priced wedge bags, half frame bags and full frame bags under its Riverside brand. This 2 litre half frame bag has two zips as well as a mesh inside divider and a mesh outer pocket. It’s attached with a total of five straps, so Decathlon says it should be stable.

The downside is that it’s not fully waterproof, being IPX3 rated and with stitched seams and standard zips, although Decathlon does also sell the 3 litre IPX6 waterproof ADVT 900 bag too.

  • Buy now from Decathlon (£24.99)

Tailfin Frame Bag

From £105 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 1.9, 2.7, 3.5 wedge, 2.3 – 6.5 litre half frame

Tailfin has three wedge bags and six half frame bags in its range with a maximum 6.5 litre capacity, so there are plenty of options to fit different bikes and requirements. Wedge bags make it easier to fit and use a larger second water bottle, while full length bags should work with a 500ml seat tube bottle on all but smaller frames.

The bags are tapered, with a maximum 64mm width that tapers to 52mm and an internal carbon frame, to maintain rigidity and help avoid rubbing when pedalling. They have welded seams and construction and attach with TPU straps and V-mounts on the top of the bag itself to help stop movement and rubbing of the frame.

  • Buy now from Tailfin (£105)

Topeak Midloader

From £44.99 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 3, 4.5, 6 litre

Topeak’s Midloader bag uses hook and loop top tube straps, plus two webbing straps to attach to your bike. There are two water resistant zips and the 60mm width is about right to avoid rubbing on your legs.

The construction isn’t quite a rigid as some other options, which might make packing easier, but means you need to avoid overfilling and bulging. There’s a 0.6 litre Gravel Gear Bag available too, if you just want somewhere for the ride essentials.

  • Buy now from Cyclestore (£56.94)

Wizard Works Osyth Partial Frame Bag

From £86 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 1.9, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5 litre, plus custom

Wizard Works uses an elastic lace system to lash your bag to the top tube, which offers more points of attachment than the more standard straps and avoids strain on the single side water-resistant zip It also supplies straps if you prefer to use these for mounting.

There are a total of six colours available, including a black reflective option and Wizard Works will also make you a custom bag. If you want more capacity, the Forres full frame bag comes in four sizes and will fit from 5 to 9.5 litres.

  • Buy now from Wizard Works (£86.00)

Zefal Z Adventure

From €35.79 | View offer

  • Sizes available: 2.5, 3.3, 4.2 litre

Zefal offers three sizes of its Z Adventure packs. They’re all IPX4 rated, with welded seams and a waterproof zip, and so provide moderate weatherproofing that will keep contents dry in most conditions, although not in a deluge. They’re mounted with two self-gripping top tube straps and a down tube strap, so they’re better suited to lighter contents.

On the plus side, they’re more affordable than many options, have a wide opening, an internal zipped pocket and 65mm width and even the largest size has a 238g quoted weight.

  • Buy now from Cyclestore (£38.95)

Bicycle frame bags: how to choose

How much capacity do you need?

How much you want to carry will be the major factor in deciding on the best frame bag for you. If you’re just looking for somewhere to add extra food or carry spares, then you may be okay with a small capacity bag.

If, on the other hand, you’re off on a bikepacking expedition, you may want a frame bag with significantly larger capacity to carry a rain jacket, food or even tent poles.

Once you’ve decided how much you want to pack, you’ll be well set to decide on the style of bag you need.

What type of bag do you want?

There are three main categories of bike frame bags.

First are wedge packs, which fit between your bike’s top tube and down tube and don’t fill the front triangle. These will have the smallest capacity, but provide a good option is you have less to carry, as they’re the least likely to interfere with pedalling. As with top tube bags, some may even make you more aero by promoting smoother airflow behind the head tube.

Next are top tube bags. These extend along the majority of the top tube, or its entirety. Their primary anchor may be at the head tube or the seat tube. They’ll take up more space and provide more volume, but except in the smallest frames will probably allow you to carry two water bottles on the frame.

Finally, full frame bags fill the entire front triangle. They provide plenty of carrying capacity, but at the expense of bottle cages. You may be able to fit a bladder inside and use a drinking tube to make up for this. Many gravel bikes and some endurance bikes or all-road bikes have mounts for a bottle cage under the down tube, which could be used to increase water capacity, although not in a manner that allows drinking on the go.

Will it fit on your bike?

Wedge packs will fit on the majority of bikes, although they may be more awkward to slot behind the head tube if your frame is small or very large.

It’s more difficult with top tube or full frame bags, where you need to consider the dimensions of your frame. Fortunately, most frame bags are available with different dimensions and capacities to suit a range of frame sizes. If your frame is particularly awkwardly shaped, a custom frame bag is available from a few of the brands above and is a relatively inexpensive option.

How waterproof should your bag be?

It’s also worth considering how waterproof you want your frame bag to be. There’s a premium for waterproof fabrics and zips and welded seams. If all you’re going to carry is a jacket or a few gels for a day ride, you might be happy to forego full waterproofing for a lower bag price.

If, on the other hand, you’re off on a multi-day ride, you probably want to make sure that the contents of your frame bag will stay dry and decide to invest in greater waterproofing.

In any case, it’s a good idea to keep anything delicate, including a phone and non-sealed food in dry bags inside the frame bag, so you can be sure they won’t end up soggy.
